annotations.paragraph: The worry for a long time has been that the world will slip out of this system. There have been challengers: Japan in the 1980s, the European Union in the 2000s and now China.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on challenges to the dollar system.

annotations.paragraph: But no one has really come anywhere near dislodging it. And that was partially because it’s hard to build something new. And partially because we were fairly, at least until recently, restrained in how we used it. We are, in a way, selling the world our currency and our financial system to make it easier for them to do their transactions. We don’t want to make it too hard to use something we’re selling.
annotations.reason: Explains why the dollar system has remained dominant.

annotations.paragraph: The Trump administration is in a much more complicated relationship with this, to say the least. They’ve come to see dollar dominance — and its cousin, our military dominance — as a burden we bear on behalf of the rest of the world, and a burden other countries should be paying more for the privilege of using. They think that having dollar dominance has made the dollar too expensive — which has hurt manufacturing even if it has meant cheap consumer goods. And they think that it has given us a leverage that all the idiots who came before them haven’t used. But Trump and his administration are going to use it.
annotations.reason: Discusses the Trump administration's perspective on dollar dominance.

annotations.paragraph: Kenneth Rogoff is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund. He’s a professor of economics at Harvard, and he has a new book coming out — very well timed — it drops on May 6 — called “Our Dollar, Your Problem.” It’s a history of dollar dominance — how we built it, the challenges to it, and a warning, written before the Trump administration, that the rest of the world was already beginning to look for exits from it.
annotations.reason: Introduces an expert and his relevant work on the topic.

annotations.paragraph: But now the Trump administration has taken the stress the system has been under and has begun to put cracks in it. Rogoff doesn’t think we’re going to be able to unring that bell. But even bigger than that: The possibility that when you bring together our debt, pressure on the dollar, Trump’s behavior — that these things could create a genuine financial crisis, a debt crisis, an inflationary crisis. And Rogoff thinks we are way underrating the risk of it.
annotations.reason: Highlights potential financial risks under the Trump administration.

annotations.paragraph: Ezra Klein: Ken Rogoff, welcome to the show.
annotations.reason: This is a standard introductory exchange in an interview.

annotations.paragraph: Kenneth Rogoff: Thank you for having me, Ezra.
annotations.reason: This is a standard introductory exchange in an interview.

annotations.paragraph: I want to get at the basics of how the dollar works in the international financial system. We sell dollars to other countries, and other countries buy them. Why?
annotations.reason: This introduces a key topic relevant to the headline about the dollar's role in the international financial system.

annotations.paragraph: The most important thing is the English language analogy: It’s something everyone understands. Partly they know what it is and partly they like it. It’s something they know and trust.
annotations.reason: This provides an analogy to explain why the dollar is widely used, relevant to the discussion of the dollar's role.

annotations.paragraph: There are 150-plus currencies in the world. Just imagine two people trying to communicate with two currencies they never saw: Let’s just deal in dollars.
annotations.reason: This illustrates the convenience and trust in using the dollar, relevant to the topic of its international use.

annotations.paragraph: So that’s a big part of it. It’s like a common language.
annotations.reason: The paragraph is vague and does not provide specific information related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: How did we build that trust?
annotations.reason: This is a rhetorical question that does not provide new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Part of how we built the trust early was the dollar was good as gold. It used to be that the dollar bill that you had in your pocket actually said how much it was worth in gold, and you could take it to various banks and get gold for it. And that actually continued for countries until just over 50 years ago.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about the dollar's value, which is relevant to understanding its current status.

annotations.paragraph: And then we moved to its not being based on gold but rather its being based on trust in the United States — and in how we would manage the dollar.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the transition from the gold standard to trust-based value, relevant to the topic.

annotations.paragraph: Well, we did. But we didn’t tell anyone we were going to do that, and they weren’t very happy about it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph hints at a historical decision regarding the dollar, relevant to the topic.

annotations.paragraph: They were holding dollars because they were as good as gold, and they literally meant gold. And when President Nixon in 1971 decided: Hmm, I don’t want to do that anymore — it was just a shock. It was actually, I think, the biggest shock until recently.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context relevant to the discussion of the dollar's value.

annotations.paragraph: But something you often run into when you start trying to study this is the intensity of the demand for dollar-backed assets. And one thing other countries don’t have is the depth of the assets we have to sell.
annotations.reason: Discusses the demand for dollar-backed assets, relevant to the article's focus on the dollar.

annotations.paragraph: So it’s not just that the dollar and dollar-backed assets like Treasuries are basically, as you put it, the lingua franca of international finance. It’s also that there are enough of them to go around. There’s just not as much liquidity in, say, German currency —

annotations.paragraph: “Liquidity” is an important word. It means: If you want to sell it, do you have to pay a big discount?
annotations.reason: Defines liquidity, which is relevant to understanding the financial context of the article.

annotations.paragraph: If you want to sell your house, you can sell it. But it’s not necessarily something you can sell quickly.
annotations.reason: Provides an analogy for liquidity, which is relevant to the financial discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Say you’re from India, and you buy a Treasury bill. You can sell it to anyone in the world. They know what it is. annotations.paragraph: So deep financial markets. Rule of law. There are other things — like open to trade because you can get your money in and out. We’ve had a very open system.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context on the factors contributing to the strength of the US dollar.

annotations.paragraph: I want to be careful, though, about just saying: The more we print, the more the demand for it. Nothing could be further from the truth. As we have more and more debt, the interest rate we pay actually goes up after a while. So there’s a trade-off. Nevertheless, we pay a lower interest rate than we would if we were another country trying to do the same thing.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the implications of US debt on interest rates, relevant to the dollar's value.

annotations.paragraph: So this moves us into the question of what we get for this dominance. Why do we want other countries to buy dollars?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a key question about the benefits of dollar dominance.

annotations.paragraph: It’s free money to us. So when they are buying currency, which are the dollar bills in your pocket, that doesn’t pay any interest. And in a way, they’re making an interest-free loan to us.

annotations.paragraph: There are different estimates of how much is abroad, but at least a trillion dollars are held abroad — interest-free loan.
annotations.reason: This provides context on the amount of U.S. dollars held abroad, relevant to the economic discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Much more important is that when they make loans to us in dollars — and that’s the Treasury, could even be your mortgage getting repurchased somehow — because it’s in dollars, historically, it has paid a lower interest rate. annotations.paragraph: What are the estimates of how much lower borrowing costs and interest rates are in America because the whole world is working off our financial system?

annotations.paragraph: A short answer is: For the government, half a percent to a percent is the range of the estimates. That doesn’t mean that we’re paying a lower rate than Germany because we borrow so much more than Germany. Be very careful about that. But given how much we’re borrowing, think half a percent to a percent.
annotations.reason: This provides specific estimates on borrowing costs, directly relevant to the economic discussion.

annotations.paragraph: You may ask: What does that matter? When you owe $36 trillion going on $37 trillion, that’s real money, each percent.
annotations.reason: This highlights the significance of borrowing costs in the context of national debt, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: But it’s not just the government. It’s your mortgage, your car loan. It pushes down interest rates all over. Those things like your mortgage and your car loan can get repackaged in some complicated way, pushed out to Germany, to Japan, to someone else.

annotations.paragraph: So it’s affecting everything. People like to have dollars because it’s the best-known currency.

annotations.paragraph: Tell me about some of the other benefits. The dollar dominance gets called the exorbitant privilege.
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces a concept relevant to the dollar's global role.

annotations.paragraph: Your book is so interesting to read in this moment because it comes from the perspective that this is this huge privilege America has that other countries in the world are growing tired of. And the question is: Can we maintain it?
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the global perception of the dollar's dominance.

annotations.paragraph: And the book is coming out at this moment when the administration is more or less claiming it to be a burden that other countries in the world are free riding off and that we need to begin to pull it back.

annotations.paragraph: So why, to the rest of the world, does this seem like a great benefit for us?

annotations.paragraph: The phrase “exorbitant privilege” was coined by Valéry Giscard d’Estaing — literally pardon my French, I’m not saying his name correctly — who didn’t like the idea that the U.S. seemed to pay a lower interest rate. annotations.paragraph: That’s really the risk. That’s definitely one of the benefits of being able to borrow a lot when you really, really need it.

annotations.paragraph: One of my general critiques of the Trump administration is they want to make complex problems into simple problems. They want to take complex forces that we don’t even really fully know how to track and turn them into one thing that you can grab in your fist and squeeze.
